Limited Liability Companies

) Purpose. This IRM section explains how to properly address various LLC lection issues and pursue administrative collection actions against the and LLC taxpayer entity. Because state law governs an LLC’s property rights may be different from that of a corporation or a partnership, the collection actions taken may also differ. It is important to determine how the LLC is classiﬁed, whether the LLC made a check-the-box election, and whether the liable taxpayer is a single member or multi-member LLC. (
) Audience. These procedures apply to IRS Field Collection revenue officers and group managers. (
) Policy Owner. The Director, Collection Policy, SB/SE is the policy owner of this IRM. (
) Program Owner. Collection Policy, SB/SE, Employment Tax (ET) is the program owner of this IRM. (
) Primary Stakeholder. The primary stakeholder of this section is Field tion. (

) Program Goals. As a form of business organization, LLCs have different acteristics than corporations or sole proprietorships. Employees must understand how to apply IRS processes and procedures to LLCs. By the guidance in this IRM, employees will be able to properly address LLC collection issues and pursue administrative collection actions against correct taxpayer entity when required. (

The changes are retroactive and they do not change the tax treatment of employment and excise taxes that accrued prior to their effective dates. The applicability of these regulations must be considered when determining liability for employ- ment and excise taxes incurred both before and after the effective dates of these regulations. (

Term Deﬁnition Limited Liability Company A limited liability company (LLC) (LLC) is an entity created by state statute that has characteristics of both a partnership and corpora- tion. • It has pass-through taxation of a partnership or sole proprietorship combined with limited liability of a corporation. • For state purposes, an LLC is a business separate from its owner in which the owner is protected from the LLC’s acts and debts, such as bankruptcy and lawsuits. • For federal tax purposes, an LLC is disregarded as separate from its owner, therefore is liable for taxes. Notice 99-6 As of January 1, 2009, Notice 99-6 is obsolete and the following applies: • Employment tax liabilities that accrue on or after January 1, 2009 may no longer be reported in the name and EIN of the SMO. • Employment taxes must be reported in the name and EIN of the LLC. • The LLC is always the liable taxpayer regardless of its tax classiﬁcation (sole-proprietorship, part- nership, or corporation). • The TFRP must be investi- gated and assessed if necessary. A limited liability company (LLC) is an entity created under state law characteristics of both a partnership and a corporation. It is similar to
Corporation in that the owners have limited personal liability negligent acts and LLC debts.
Partnership in that it provides management ﬂexibility and may the beneﬁt of pass

through taxation of income. An LLC may own property, enter into contracts and otherwise business in its own name. Property ownership is governed by state State LLC statutes include a number of common elements and many of which are different from other types of business The following are some of the characteristics of an LLC:
Owners are called members.
There are no restrictions on ownership.
There are no restrictions on the number of members.
Single member LLCs are permitted. An LLC with one owner is a single member entity. An LLC with more than one owner is a multi
member entity. The treatment of an LLC for tax purposes may depend in part on LLC is a single member entity or a multi
member entity. Classiﬁcation of the LLC for federal tax purposes does not negate provisions concerning the legal status of the LLC. For example:
An LLC classiﬁed as a partnership for federal tax purposes mean the member/owners have liability for LLC debts as case in a partnership under state law.

(01-12-2015) Characteristics of a Limited Liability Company (LLC)
Classiﬁcation of the LLC for federal tax purposes does not negate state law provisions concerning the legal status of the LLC. For example:
An LLC classiﬁed as a partnership for federal tax purposes does not mean the member/owners have liability for LLC debts as would be the case in a partnership under state law.

• An LLC that is a disregarded entity is treated as a sole proprietorship it is owned by an individual. If the disregarded entity is owned by any other entity, it is treated as a branch or division of its owner. (

effective date (generally no more than 90 days after ﬁling) or include additional provisions when organizing documents are ﬁled before the LLC has at least one member. Check your state statute to determine when an LLC is officially formed.

) Many states require an LLC to ﬁle an annual report with the designated state official. Reports may include: • Name and address of the registered agent for the LLC • Principal business address of the company • Name of the manager of the LLC • Names of one or more of the members Note: Many state statutes do not require the LLC to provide complete ownership information to the Secretary of State or equivalent. (

) Provisions for Operating Agreements vary widely according to state law. They may be known as Limited Liability Company Agreements or By-laws and are optional in some states. These documents are not generally required to be ﬁled with the Secretary of State’s office. Many states allow them to be written or oral. (

) The Operating Agreement may provide some or all of the following • Responsibilities of the members within the LLC • Name and address of one or more of the members • Signature of the members that adopted the Operating Agreement • Name of the attorney that drafted the Operating Agreement • Indication as to whether members share in management of the LLC, or if there is a designated manager • Name and address of one or more of the managers • Initial capital contributions • Initial shares • Allocation of distribution of proﬁts amongst members (which may differ from their ownership interest) • Powers of the manager as signatory on bank accounts (

) Since the LLC is often the most useful source of information, secure as much information as possible on initial contact. Most state statutes require the LLC maintain complete ownership records and other information at the place of business. This includes some or all of the following: • Number of members of the LLC • Name(s), address(es), and TIN(s) of all members, along with dates of ownership and amount of their interest in the LLC • Information regarding the designation of a manager of the LLC, if appli- cable, along with the dates of service and a record of the manager’s responsibilities • Copy of the Operating Agreement • Articles of Organization or similar documents • Minutes of meetings of members of the LLC Note: If supporting documentation is not readily available to determine the of members of an LLC that made no elections, consider issuing a summons for original documents or for testimony, or secure an affidavit from the

) Identify the liable taxpayer before issuing Letter

, Final Notice, Notice Intent to Levy and Notice of Your Right to a Hearing, so the correct entity is notiﬁed of their right to a Collection Due Process (CDP) hearing. Document your history with the basis for your determination of the liable taxpayer. • When the LLC is the taxpayer, the CDP notice is issued in the name the LLC and the LLC has the right to a CDP hearing. • When the SMO is the taxpayer, the CDP notice must be issued in name of the SMO and the SMO has the right to a CDP hearing. (

) When a member of an LLC is liable for federal taxes, a Notice of Levy may served on the LLC to attach distributions payable to the member when the right to receive income from the LLC is “property” or a “right to property” of state law. (

) Under most state laws, a member of an LLC has a right to receive a share the LLC’s proﬁts and losses, unless otherwise provided in the LLC’s agreement. Consult with Area Counsel, if necessary, to determine the member’s property rights under state law. (

) A levy will attach property possessed and obligations existing at the time of levy. Obligations exist when the liability of the obligor is ﬁxed and determin- able, although the right to receive payment may be deferred until a later Courts have held that the “ﬁxed and determinable” requirement in Treas.

) is satisﬁed when the events which give rise to the have occurred and the amount of the obligation is capable of being in the future. Under this rationale, a levy could be served upon the LLC to attach income to which the member is entitled for services rendered prior to the service of the notice of levy, after the LLC sets aside a reserve for overhead expenses. (
) Generally, a levy extends only to property possessed and obligations which exist at the time of levy. An exception to this rule, IRC
(e), authorizes a continuous levy on salary or wages, but does not specify the types of remu- neration that are covered by the terms “salary or wages.” (
) Courts have held that, under certain circumstances, recurring payments that are made as draws or advances on future income may be subject to the tinuous wage levy provision of IRC
(e). Consider using the Service’s summons authority to determine the frequency with which the owner takes draws of proﬁts from the LLC. (
) Consult with Area Counsel to determine whether the facts are sufficient to support a continuous wage levy, using Form

-A, Notice Levy, should be served to attach to the property of or obligations owed to owner at the time of levy. (

) For foreign eligible entities, the default classiﬁcation may change if the of members without limited liability changes. (
) A change in ownership that affects the LLC’s classiﬁcation is not an elective change, so there is no sixty-month limitation on the frequency of such changes.
